title: 110_hr3363
content: The Act titled "Long-Term Care Affordability and Security Act of 2007" addresses the treatment of premiums on qualified long-term care insurance contracts. The Act "Long-Term Care Affordability and Security Act of 2007" includes amendments to the Internal Revenue Code regarding cafeteria plans and flexible spending arrangements for long-term care insurance premiums. The Act "Long-Term Care Affordability and Security Act of 2007" includes amendments to the Internal Revenue Code regarding cafeteria plans and flexible spending arrangements for long-term care insurance premiums. A flexible spending arrangement is defined as a benefit program that allows reimbursement of specified expenses, with a maximum reimbursement limit of less than 500 percent of the coverage value. Various sections of the Code are amended to reflect these changes. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2006, affecting sections 3306(b)(18), 3401(a)(22), 4973(g)(1), and 4973(g)(2)(B)(i). Section 6041(f)(1) of the Code is amended by removing the definition of "as defined in section 106(c)(2)". SEC. 3. Additional consumer protections for long-term care insurance. Additional Protections Applicable to Long-Term Care Insurance under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 require meeting specific model regulation requirements, including guaranteed renewal or noncancellability. The text chunk relates to various sections (6B, 6C, 6D, 6E, 7, 8) of the Act, excluding specific paragraphs, regarding prohibitions, extension of benefits, continuation of coverage, discontinuance of policies, unintentional lapse, and other related provisions. The curr_chunk summarizes sections 8, 11, 12, 13, and 25 of the Act, which cover disclosure, prohibitions against post-claims underwriting, minimum standards, requirement to offer inflation protection, and prohibition against preexisting conditions in replacement policies. The curr_chunk outlines requirements related to replacement policies, including contingent nonforfeiture benefits and specific provisions from the model Act regarding preexisting conditions and prior hospitalization. The curr_chunk discusses contingent nonforfeiture benefits in relation to policyholder decisions on nonforfeiture provisions. Definitions for terms like 'model regulation' and 'model Act' are provided based on the long-term care insurance model regulation by the NAIC. The curr_chunk discusses the coordination and determination of provisions in the model regulation or model Act promulgated by the NAIC. It also mentions the excise tax under section 4980C(c) of the Internal Revenue Code. The excise tax under section 4980C(c) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to include requirements of the model regulation, such as disclosure of rating practices, application forms, reporting, filing, and marketing standards.
